parent_formation: Eighth Army (various commands due to dispersal)

commander.name: Francis Tuker
commander.previous_service: Assumed command October 1941, commanded until February 1944

command.headquarters_location: Dispersed - No central HQ (brigades in Cyprus, Syria, Egypt)

Marmon-Herrington.role: Reconnaissance (Central India Horse detached to Iraq)

QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.note: 3 field artillery regiments x 24 guns each (when division assembled)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critically disrupted due to division dispersal across four theaters (Cyprus, Syria, Egypt, Iraq). Brigades operating independently with separate supply lines. 11th Brigade supply cut off during Tobruk siege (May-June). 5th Brigade rushed to desert with minimal stocks June 1942.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Multiple theaters: Cyprus (mountainous coast), Syria (desert/mountains), Egypt (coastal desert - Suez/Mersa Matruh), Libya (coastal desert - Tobruk)

subordinate_units.location: Syria (April-May), rushed to Egypt June 1942, Ruweisat Ridge July-August 1942

battalions: Unknown - detached to Cyprus garrison duties

subordinate_units.location: Suez Canal Zone training (April), Tobruk May-June 1942 (attached to 5th Indian Division), captured 21 June 1942

tactical_doctrine.role: Division NOT operational as cohesive unit during 1942-Q2. Brigades dispersed to separate theaters for garrison/training duties. GOC Tuker strongly opposed dispersal. 11th Brigade saw combat at Tobruk (captured). 5th Brigade rushed to First Alamein July 1942. Division not reunited until October 1942.
special_capabilities: Mountain warfare expertise (utilized later in Italy)
Experienced in desert warfare from Operation Compass 1940-41
known_issues: Division dispersed - not functioning as unified formation
11th Brigade captured at Tobruk siege (21 June 1942) - 3,800 men lost
Brigades under separate commands in four different theaters
GOC Tuker's repeated protests about dispersal
No divisional-level training or operations possible
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Previous desert experience from 1940-41, but dispersal prevented application of lessons learned. Individual brigades adapted to local conditions (Cyprus mountains, Syrian terrain, Egyptian desert).

scenario_suitability: Brigade-level scenarios only (division not operational as unit)
First Battle of El Alamein - Ruweisat Ridge (5th Brigade, July 1942)
special_rules: Division DISPERSED - use brigade-level units independently
11th Brigade: Captured at Tobruk - remove from OOB after 21 June 1942
5th Brigade: Arrives desert theater June 1942 with supply penalties
Central India Horse: Detached to Iraq theater
historical_engagements: First Battle of El Alamein - Ruweisat Ridge (5th Brigade, July-August 1942)
Second Battle of El Alamein (division reunited, October 1942)

source: British Army Lists (April 1942, July 1942) - Official UK Ministry of Defence records, confidence 95%

The Gurkha Museum (Winchester, UK) - 'Gurkhas and the Fall of Tobruk, 21st June 1942' - museum archival source documenting 11th Indian Brigade composition (2/7th Gurkhas under Lt-Col Orgill, 2nd Camerons, 2/5th Mahrattas), combat actions, and capture at Tobruk, confidence 90%

Battle Orders 028: Desert Rats - British 8th Army in North Africa 1941-43 (Osprey Publishing) - pages 13, 41, 81-90 - confirms 4th Indian Division as veteran formation in 8th Army, Francis Tuker as commander, and division's use of 7th Indian Brigade in April 1943 operations, confidence 85%
TM 30-410: Handbook on the British Army (1942) - US War Department official manual for Indian division establishment structures, confidence 90%

supply_logistics.reason: Division dispersed across 4 theaters with separate supply chains. No unified logistics possible. 11th Brigade supply cut off at Tobruk. 5th Brigade rushed to desert with minimal preparation.
sources_checked: British Army Lists (April/July 1942) - no logistics data in personnel lists
Desert Rats Osprey (pages 1-100) - operational narrative only
The Gurkha Museum - Tobruk article documents ammunition exhaustion but no detailed logistics
TM 30-410 British Army Handbook - provides establishment templates but not operational logistics
supply_logistics.mitigation: Set values to 0 with explanatory note in supply_status field documenting dispersal situation

7th_brigade_battalions_1942q2.reason: Battalion compositions for 7th Indian Brigade during April-June 1942 Cyprus deployment not found in available sources. Brigade was on garrison duties, separate from division. Desert Rats Osprey confirms 7th Brigade used in April 1943 operations but does not provide 1942-Q2 composition.
sources_checked: British Army Lists (April/July 1942) - lists brigade but not battalion assignments
The Gurkha Museum - focused on 11th Brigade at Tobruk
Desert Rats Osprey - mentions 7th Indian Brigade in 1943 operations only
TM 30-410 - establishment templates, not specific assignments
7th_brigade_battalions_1942q2.mitigation: Documented 11th Brigade battalions from Gurkha Museum primary source. Noted 7th Brigade as 'Unknown' pending further research in regimental histories or National Archives UK war diaries.

personnel_exact_counts.reason: No primary sources available with exact personnel counts for 1942-Q2. Used standard Indian infantry division establishment (~11,500) but division was dispersed.
sources_checked: TM 30-410 British Army Handbook - provides establishment template (~11,500)
British Army Lists (April/July 1942) - officer assignments only, no strength returns
Desert Rats Osprey - narrative history, no personnel data
The Gurkha Museum - Tobruk article mentions 35,000 total captured but not brigade-specific strength
personnel_exact_counts.estimate_method: Applied standard Indian infantry division establishment of ~11,500 personnel (3 brigades @ 3,800 each + divisional troops). Note: Actual strength likely lower due to dispersal and 11th Brigade capture.
